awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unlocking the secrets of slow slip by drilling at the northern Hikurangi subduction margin, New Zealand: CORK observatory development and installation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Hikurangi subduction zone offshore the eastern North Island of New Zealand has characteristics that provide a globally unique window into a fundamental aspect of how stress builds up and is relieved as an oceanic plate thrusts (or ?subducts?) beneath continental crust. Recently, seismologists have recognized that subduction megathrust faults undergo slip in episodic ?slow slip events?. Prior to the discovery of slow slip events in the last decade, our paradigms of fault slip were focused on seismic slip in major earthquakes. Since the discovery of slow slip, most studies have focused on deep (>20-40 km depth) slow slip events, but we now realize that shallow slow slip events (<5-15 km depth) exist that are much more accessible to near-source investigations. These shallow slow fault slip events are centered beneath the ocean so onshore instruments have not been able to measure how much surface deformation occurs. This study takes advantage of planned International Ocean Discovery Program drilling to install sensors in two boreholes that will measure properties indicative of change in the shallow crust that the episodic fault activity causes.  Senior researchers in borehole instrumentation will mentor mid-early career scientists, passing along extensive knowledge of such complex implementation and research. Japanese, New Zealand, and German collaborators will participate with the US investigators in this international study, and local communities will benefit from scientist outreach associated with cruises off New Zealand. This study is being undertaken as a ?community proposal?, whereby all data will be immediately publicly available.
 
The shallowest, well-documented slow slip events on Earth occur at the northern Hikurangi margin, offshore Gisborne, New Zealand, at <5-15 km depth. They recur approximately every 1-2 years, with slip on the plate boundary interface of up to 15-20 cm. The unusually close proximity of the Gisborne slow slip events to the seafloor, the large slow slip event magnitudes (equivalent to an earthquake magnitude Mw ~6.3-6.8), and short recurrence intervals makes this the ideal setting for evaluating the near-source hydrological, geochemical, and thermal response of the offshore subduction margin to large, frequent, well-documented deformation transients. The borehole observatory data will clarify the role that fluid pressures, fluid flow, and temperature play in the occurrence of slow slip events, as well as the influence of slow slip event deformation on fluid and geochemical cycling within the forearc. This project will establish the borehole facility and set-up open data access. Analysis of the first two years of data, recovered by ROV, will evaluate the deformation, hydrological, and geochemical responses near the source of slow slip, as well as document the thermal regime of shallow slow slip. One of the borehole installations will target the region surrounding the shallow portion of the megathrust fault , while sensors in a second borehole will target the over-riding plate ~5 km above the slow slip event source.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Slow slip events (SSEs) involve transient aseismic slip across a fault (lasting weeks to months) at a rate intermediate between the plate boundary displacement rate and the slip velocity required to generate seismic waves. The physical mechanisms leading to SSEs, their role in plate boundary strain accumulation and release, and their relationship to destructive seismic slip on subduction zone faults are poorly known. The primary objective of this project was to design, fabricate, and install two CORK borehole observatories at the northern Hikurangi subduction zone to continuously monitor pore fluid pressure, fluid flow rates, fluid composition, and temperature through multiple slow slip cycles to better understand the dynamics of strain accumulation and release along the megathrust as well as the hydrological, geochemical, and thermal responses to fault slip.

 

This project produced an updated CORK observatory design that greatly reduces the risk of borehole collapse interfering with the installation of downhole instrumentation as well as the risk of an individual component failure compromising other parts of the installation. As such, the CORKs designed for this experiment will serve as a new standard for subseafloor observatories capable of coupled pore pressure monitoring and fluid sampling in continental margin environments and subduction zones, and in particular fault zone monitoring. One of the CORK observatories installed at the Hikurangi subduction zone included a newly designed fluid flow meter capable of continuously monitoring fluid flow rates, fluid flow direction, and fluid composition. The design includes a new fluid sampler valve that isolates the sample coils, reducing the risk of sample loss due to outgassing from the coils during recovery.

 

The two CORK observatories and downhole instrumentation were successfully installed during IODP Expedition 375 in early 2018. The observatories were subsequently visited with a remotely operated vehicle during research expeditions in 2019 and 2021 to check on the health of the installations and to download the first three years of pore pressure data. Visual inspection and the pore pressure data confirmed that both installations were indeed successful, and the CORK observatories are collecting high-quality pore fluid pressure data. The continuous pore fluid pressure data over the three-year period is spectacular with the record containing the formation pore pressure response during a large slow-slip event that occurred from April to June 2019, with 20-30 cm of slip on the plate boundary in the study area. The new CORK pressure data provides an unprecedented, long-term view of deformation both within the source region of slow slip and near the trench that is essential to understanding the dynamics of fault slip in subduction zones.

 

The new data made possible by the two CORK observatory installations at the Hikurangi subduction zone provide a powerful new window into the dynamics of SSE and megathrust behavior by enabling detection of small events and subevents, spatiotemporal variations in moment release, and relationships between SSE slip and other phenomena including tremor and microseismicity. Recovery of the downhole fluid flow meter and thermistor string from the CORKs (anticipated in 2023) will make the CORK dataset  among the most integrative geophysical records in a subduction zone, and we expect it will greatly enhance our understanding of linked hydrologic, fault mechanical, thermal, and geochemical processes in this dynamic environment.

 

Broader Impacts

The design of the CORK observatory and fluid monitoring components is the new "state of the art" for integrated geophysical/geochemical subseafloor observatories, and we expect it will serve as a foundation for future experiments in subduction zones and other continental margin environments. Furthermore, the CORKs installed at the Hikurangi subduction zone is a community facility that is available to the broader scientific community for conducting future experiments. In addition, the data and samples that will be collected will be made fully public upon acquisition (planned downhole instrument recovery in 2023). The research enabled by the two new CORK observatories will significantly contribute to ongoing efforts to constrain the nature, timing, dynamics, and hydrologic and thermal processes linked to subduction megathrust strain accumulation and release in slow slip events, advancing our understanding of the physical processes that govern fault slip and earthquakes along subduction zones.

 

Results from the project have been disseminated to the earth science research community through published reports and presentations at national/international meetings. The PIs have contributed to numerous news stories and outreach programs that have highlighted scientific ocean drilling, subseafloor observatories, and subduction zone hazards off the east coast of New Zealand. In addition, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers from both the U.S. and New Zealand participated in the research expeditions to visit the CORK installations in 2019 and 2021. The expeditions provided hands-on training in marine geological fieldwork and working with a remotely operated vehicle.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/13/2022
Modified by: Evan A Solomon
